title: Dividend Income Calculator

seo.title: Dividend Income Calculator | Project Passive Income
seo.description: Visualize your future passive income. See how dividend reinvestment (DRIP) and regular contributions can snowball into a life-changing revenue stream.

summary: The secret weapon of the wealthy? Dividends. Use this tool to see how a portfolio of dividend-growth stocks can eventually replace your salary.

faq.a: It involves buying shares of companies that not only pay dividends but consistently increase them every year (like 'Dividend Aristocrats'). Over time, this acts as an inflation hedge and increases your 'Yield on Cost'.
A Dividend Reinvestment Plan (DRIP) automatically uses your cash dividends to buy more shares of the same stock. This compounds your growth, as your new shares generate their own dividends.
This is your current dividend income divided by your *original* purchase price. If you bought Coca-Cola in 1990, your yield on cost today might be 50%+, even if the stock's current yield is only 3%.
In the US, 'Qualified Dividends' are taxed at the long-term capital gains rate (0%, 15%, or 20%). 'Non-qualified' dividends (like from REITs) are taxed at your regular income tax rate.

article.heading: The Snowball Effect of Dividends
article.body:
Dividend investing is not a get-rich-quick scheme; it is a get-rich-for-sure scheme. By reinvesting dividends, you harness the dual engines of wealth: **Capital Appreciation** (stock price goes up) and **Dividend Growth** (payouts go up).

Imagine you own 1,000 shares paying $1/share. You get $1,000. You use that to buy 20 more shares. Next year, the company raises the dividend to $1.10. Now you have 1,020 shares paying $1.10. Your income jumps to $1,122. Repeat this for 20 years, and the curve goes vertical.

article.heading: Yield vs. Growth
article.body:
There are two main strategies:
1.  **High Yield:** Buying stocks paying 4-8% today (e.g., Verizon, REITs). Good for current income, but usually low growth.
2.  **High Growth:** Buying stocks paying 1-2% today but growing the payout by 10-15% annually (e.g., Visa, Microsoft). Better for long-term total return.

This calculator lets you simulate both. Try inputting a high yield with low growth, then a low yield with high growth, and see which wins over 20 years.

article.heading: The Goal: Crossing over
article.body: The ultimate goal of dividend investing is the 'Crossover Point'â€”the day your annual dividend income exceeds your annual expenses. Unlike selling shares (the 4% rule), living off dividends leaves your principal untouched, creating generational wealth.
